Award.AwardTitle: The Integrated Behavioral Phenotype: Links Among Functionally Different Behavioral Traits
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ann Hedrick, IOS-0716332
The integrated behavioral phenotype: links among functionally different behavioral traits

Correlations among multiple kinds of behavioral traits, such as mating behavior, territorial behavior and anti-predator behavior, can limit the potential variation in an animal''s behavior on which natural selection can act. These correlations therefore may influence the course of behavioral evolution. However, they have rarely been studied in natural populations of animals. This research will examine correlations among three behavioral traits: mating displays, anti-predator behavior and fighting behavior, as well as the consequences of these correlations in a natural population of field crickets, Gryllus integer. Previous evidence shows that male crickets with more conspicuous mating displays (songs) are more cautious about the risk of predation than males with less conspicuous displays. This evidence also suggests that more aggressive males are less cautious about predation risk than less aggressive males. The project has three parts, and builds on this prior evidence. The first part will compare the mating displays and anti-predator behavior of males that win fights with the mating displays and anti-predator behavior of males that lose fights. This will yield new information on the links between mating displays, anti-predator behavior and fighting ability in a natural population of animals. The second part will test the prediction that more aggressive males will have lower survival in the presence of predators than less aggressive males because they are less cautious about the risk of predation. The last part will determine whether female mating preferences can predict which males will win fights, and will illuminate the relationship between male aggression and female choice of mates. This project will contribute to the training and development of at least nine undergraduates and several graduate students, many of whom will be minorities and women. The project also will involve international collaboration and continued participation in an outreach program for disadvantaged schoolchildren.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to examine correlations among functionally different traits (such as fighting and avoiding predators) in the field cricket, Gryllus integer. Correlations among functionally different traits are important because they can limit the potential variation in behavior on which selection can act, and therefore can influence the course of behavioral evolution. We also examined animal “personality” (consistent individual behaviors over context or time), a closely related topic.

We found that in male crickets, aggressiveness was positively correlated with “boldness”, i.e. the tendency to take risks, as opposed to “shyness”. When we measured boldness across metamorphosis, we discovered that adult females had roughly the same boldness as they had when they were nymphs (juveniles). However, males became much less bold across metamorphosis, probably because adult males call for mates, making them more vulnerable to predation. Another study on Gryllus integer asked whether boldness was related to the efficiency of immune function. It showed that fast-growing, bold individuals matured early and invested little in immune defense compared to slower growing, shy individuals.

We also studied whether juvenile crickets use acoustic sexual signals (male calling) to alter both their development and later adult aggressiveness. We predicted that males that were reared in the presence of male songs would have larger body mass and be more aggressive compared with males that were reared in silence. Surprisingly, however, we found that males reared in the presence of male song were less aggressive and less likely to be dominant relative to crickets reared in silence.

In addition, we looked at the effects of predator exposure on the boldness of crickets that had no prior experience with predators. First, we measured the boldness of the crickets. Then, we introduced a predator. Finally, we measured the boldness after the predator trial. We found that exposure to a predator affected subsequent boldness. Moreover, we found that different behavioral types (i.e. bold and shy) expressed different behavioral responses to predator introduction: shy individuals became bolder and bold animals became shyer.

Another project examined correlations between the quality of male song and aggressiveness. A prediction from current theory asserts that the quality of a male’s display (e.g. the amount of time spent calling) should indicate dominance. In contrast, our work demonstrated the opposite: we found that the quality of male display was higher for crickets that were less dominant, whereas the crickets with low-quality displays were more dominant.

In addition to the research discussed above, my laboratory was involved in an outreach program for disadvantaged K-12 children called “Watch it, don’t Squash it”. Graduate students entered classrooms and engaged the students with live exhibits and experiments. I was also interviewed by Ranger Rick and Science News. An article published in Science News that featured my research was printed in 2008. I was interviewed by Science News an additional five times.  Scienceline.org (a website) featured my work, as well as two additional websites:  "The Scent of Stud", 9/05/2012, blog, http://the-scorpion-and-thefrog.blogspot.com and “Young Cricket Characters Shaped by Song", 08/14/2012, BBC Nature News.
